Context:
Program Name: Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis
Code: S303
Credential: Honours Bachelor's Degree
Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 5 semesters + 14 week Field Experience term (Unpaid)
Starting Months: May
Domestic Tuition: $10,420.00 *
International Tuition: $29,152.00 *
Centre: Health Sciences
School: Health & Wellness
Location: Waterfront Campus
Experiential Learning: 14-week placement in the summer before semester 7
Fall 2023 Delivery: On campus (Semester 5)
Winter 2024 Delivery: Hybrid (Semesters 6 and 8)
Program Availability: Open for Spring 2024
Tuition & Fees: Domestic - $10,420.00, International - $29,152.00 *
Contact Us: Available in Program Menu

George Brown College offers a Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S303) program with a duration of 5 semesters and an additional 14-week unpaid field experience term. Domestic students pay $10,420.00 per year in tuition, while international students pay $29,152.00. The program is delivered full-time at the Health Sciences Centre located on the Waterfront Campus. Students will attend on campus for Semester 5 and have hybrid delivery for Semesters 6 and 8. The fast-track degree program is open to students who have completed two years of an approved Behavioural Science Technology or Technician program.

*Please note that these tuition fees are for reference only, as they may be subject to change and it is recommended to check with the college directly for the most up-to-date information.

Context:
Extracted Information:

1. George Brown College offers an Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S303) degree program.
2. Eligibility for the program includes students who have completed two years of the Behavioural Science Technology (C116) advanced diploma program or graduated from the Behavioural Science Technician (C146) diploma program.
3. Students will go through a bridge semester during spring/summer (semester 4).
4. The degree program focuses on Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA), which is used to modify behaviour in a desirable way.
5. ABA can be applied to populations with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), brain injury, dementia, developmental disabilities, addiction, and mental health disorders.
6. The degree program consists of three main components:
   - Component 1: Behavioural assessment
   - Component 2: Developing an effective plan based on the assessment results
   - Component 3: Ongoing evaluation of components one and two
7. The research component is a foundational aspect of the program, with students learning how to prepare an applied research proposal during semesters 5 and 6, and conducting the research during the Fall semester of their fourth year.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis Program (Year 3 Bridge) S303 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Association for Behavior Analysis International (ABAI) has verified the following courses toward the coursework requirements for the Board Certified Assistant Behaviour Analyst® examination:
- Applicants need to meet additional eligibility requirements and demonstrate they can reside in an authorized country before they can be eligible to take the examination.
- The degree program helps prepare students to become leaders in behavior analysis.
- Graduates of the program have become leaders in fields such as forensic mental health, autism spectrum disorder, and acquired brain injury.
- The intensive program is suitable for data-driven students who enjoy analyzing patterns and working with challenging behaviors.
- Core courses focus on five areas of learning: behavioral science theories, principles and methods; special populations; psychology; research methods/statistics; ethics, professionalism and leadership.
- Graduates of approved Ontario college behavioral science technology advanced diploma programs with a 3.0 GPA or higher are eligible to enter a bridging pathway that leads to the fourth year (semester 7) of the Honours Bachelors of Behaviour Analysis (S304) degree program.
- External applicants from other institutions will be assessed for advanced standing on a case-by-case basis.
- The contact email for Program Co-ordinator Don Togade is Don.Togade@georgebrown.ca.
- As of July 2024, the profession of applied behavior analysis in Ontario will come under the jurisdiction of the College of Psychologists and Behaviour Analysts of Ontario.

No information was extracted regarding any specific program offered by the college.

Context: The College of Psychologists and Behaviour Analysts of Ontario offers a Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis fast-track degree program. In the final year of the program, students participate in a 14-week unpaid field experience term between semesters 6 and 7 to conduct a research thesis. Students will be supported by a field coordinator during placement preparation and interviews. ABA practitioners may find various career opportunities such as assessment, development and implementation of skill acquisition programs, functional assessment of challenging behaviours, behaviour management plans, data collection and analysis, case management, autism spectrum disorders consultant, behaviour technician, behaviour therapist, behavioural consultant, behavioural specialist, instructor therapist, recreational therapist, residential support worker, transition co-ordinator, and vocational support worker. Graduates of the program have pursued master's degrees in Applied Behaviour Analysis, Applied Disability Studies, counselling psychology at Brock University, The Chicago School of Professional Psychology, Missouri State University, Western University, University of British Columbia, and Yorkville University. Additionally, graduates interested in working in long-term care facilities can consider applying to the Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care (S417) postgraduate certificate program, which is a two-semester program where students learn to coordinate and manage an interprofessional healthcare team of complex and long-term care professionals.

Context:
The text provides information about the curriculum of a Behavior Analysis graduate program offered by the college. Here is the extracted information:

Program: Behavior Analysis
Semesters and Courses:
- Semester 4: BEHA 2106, BEHA 2107, BEHA 2111, BEHA 2112, Liberal Studies Elective
- Semester 5: BEHA 2103, BEHA 3001, BEHA 3002, BEHA 3004, Liberal Studies Elective
- Semester 6: BEHA 3101, BEHA 3102, BEHA 3109, BEHA 3110, BEHA 4002, Liberal Studies Elective
- Semester 7: BEHA 3103, BEHA 4001, BEHA 4003, BEHA 4004, Liberal Studies Elective, Fall: BEHA 4000 – Work Experience (unpaid)
- Semester 8: BEHA 4101, BEHA 4102, BEHA 4103, BEHA 4104, BEHA 4105, Liberal Studies Elective

Course Titles: Advanced Research Design and Statistics, Advanced Assessment Strategies and Behaviour Theory, Skill Acquisition: Advanced Theory and Application II, Treating Challenging Behaviours II, Behavioural Approaches to Autism, Development Disabilities and Other Behavioural Issues, Group Behaviour Therapy, Behavioural Approaches to Acquired Brain Injury and Gerontology, Psychometrics, Standards of Practice in ABA, Clinical Behaviour Analysis, Mediator Training: Applications to Parents and Staff, Supervision Seminar II, Block Placement II, Behavioural Approaches to Health and Well-Being, Behavioural Approaches to Education, Organizational Behaviour Management, Service Delivery Systems and Interprofessional Practice, Consolidation of Behavioural Principles and Practice, Advanced Topics in Behavioural Science, Leadership in Behaviour Analysis, Professional Standards and Practices in Dissemination, Thesis (42 hours)

Learning Outcomes:
- Learn about psychological theory, research and practices.
- Design and conduct various assessments across a variety of settings and populations.
- Design and implement research-based programs in applied settings.

Context:
The text provides information about a program offered by George Brown College in Applied Behaviour Analysis. Here are the key facts extracted from the text:

1. The program includes various assessments across different settings and populations.
2. Students will design, implement, and evaluate research-based programs in applied behaviour analysis.
3. Practical skills training with different populations.
4. Demonstration of professional and clinical skills in an interdisciplinary setting.
5. Maintenance of high ethical standards and communication skills (orally and written).
6. Understanding and critical evaluation of societal issues.
7. Tuition fees: Domestic - $10,420.00; International - $29,152.00 for the first three semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022.
8. Financial assistance available through OSAP for eligible applicants.
9. Admission requirements: Completion of a two-year Behavioural Science Technology advanced diploma program or equivalent, with a minimum GPA of 3.0; English language proficiency required at specific levels.
10. Course exemptions may be granted based on college and university credits.
11. Contact Don Togade for International Students applications.
12. The program is approved for a seven-year term starting July 21, 2015.

Context:
The college offers an applied degree with a seven-year term starting July 21, 2015. Students admitted during this period are required to complete the program within a reasonable time frame.

Special requirements for students include:
- Completing mandatory pre-placement health form requirements and submitting proof of medical records, police vulnerable sector checks, Standard First Aid certificates, CPR level HCP certificates, annual flu shots, and mask fit tests by given deadlines to ParaMed.
- Meeting the requirements to ensure protection of clients and vulnerable populations.
- Completing a Police Vulnerable Sector Check renewed every year.
- Paying for all costs associated with the overall health requirements.

The police vulnerable sector check process can take two to three months, but may take up to four to eight months under certain circumstances. It is required to protect the clientele of placement partner agencies, who are considered "vulnerable persons" under the law.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis Program (Year 3 Bridge) S303 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Students are required to provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check for field or clinical placements. Those unable to do so may not be able to complete the program and will jeopardize their progress. The fees for the police record check vary and must be paid by the student (for more information, visit the Pre-placement website). Students who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may not be able to complete the required field placement component of their program in the regularly scheduled time frame.

Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges. For program information, contact 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or email hwprograms@georgebrown.ca. Related programs include Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S302), Autism and Behavioural Science (Postgraduate) (C405), and Behavioural Science Technician (C146). Campus tours can be booked, and applicants can sign up to receive tailored resources for their application process.

Fees for police record checks vary. Contact the Pre-placement website for more information. Students who are unable to provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check or who are not fully vaccinated against COVID-19 may face challenges completing their program in the regularly scheduled time frame.
